answers.answerText: A. Discrete area of subretinal hyper-reflective collection temporal to the optic disc
B. Juxtapapillary intra-retinal hyper-reflectivity overlying the temporal aspect of optic disc with choroidal extension

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/oncology1-7_jpg.webp)

OCT of the optic nerve OS demonstrates a notable area of sub-retinal hyper-reflectivity (red arrow) with adjacent juxtapapillary intra-retinal hyper-reflectivity corresponding to the lesion seen on examination. The ellipsoid zone appears attenuated leading into the sub-retinal hyper-reflectivity (white arrow). The optic nerve has normal contour with no signs of excavation.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What finding is not appreciated in this OCT optic nerve above?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
Your colleague shares an OCT of an optic nerve with known melanocytoma for your reference:

![](/content/media/oncology1-8.webp)

What is the biggest difference in the known melanocytoma OCT above compared to the OCT of our patient presentation?

answers.answerText: A. Anterior hyper-reflective border with associated hyper-reflective foci and posterior shadowing
answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/oncology1-9.webp)

Melanocytomas are benign magnocellular nevi which can occur anywhere where uveal melanocytes are present, most commonly in the optic disc, but also the choroid, ciliary body, iris and sclera. On OCT, optic nerve melanocytomas are characterized by hyper-reflectivity at its anterior tumor surface (red arrow) with dense posterior shadowing (blue arrow) with an optically empty appearance. Hyper-reflective foci (yellow arrows) are often seen within the tumor, which are characteristic of melanocytomas.

**References:**

1. Raval V, Reddy R, Kaliki S, Das T. Optical coherence tomography and optical coherence tomography angiography features of optic nerve head melanocytoma: Valuable biomarkers. Invest Ophthalmol Vis Sci. 2020;61(7):4827.
2. Shields CL, Perez B, Benavides R, Materin MA, Shields JA. Optical coherence tomography of optic disk melanocytoma in 15 cases. Retina. 2008 Mar;28(3):441-6.

answers.answerText: B. Hypo-reflective foci surrounding the lesion

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Which of the following OCT findings is NOT usually seen in melanocytomas?

answers.answerText: B. Optical shadowing of posterior layers
C. Retinal disorganization adjacent to or over tumor

answers.explanation:
In a study by Shields et al (2008), OCT was performed on 15 cases of optic disc melanocytomas. While vitreous seeds and adjacent retinal edema was noted in a small percentage of their cases, macular edema was not seen in any cases. Optic disc melanocytoma usually has a nodular appearance with a hyper-reflective anterior tumor border with optical shadowing of the posterior layers. Retinal disorganization is often noticed adjacent to or over the tumor.  

 **References:**

1. Shields CL, Perez B, Benavides R, Materin MA, Shields JA. Optical coherence tomography of optic disk melanocytoma in 15 cases. Retina. 2008 Mar;28(3):441-6.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
Back to our patient presentation, a flow B-scan OCT angiography with corresponding en-face OCT of the outer retina/choriocapillaris layer is shown below:

![](/content/media/oncology1-10.webp)

answers.explanation: The most prominent finding is choroidal neovascularization, correlating to the hyper-reflective intra-retinal region seen on OCT of the optic nerve. En-face helps to characterize this neovascularization in the outer retina and choriocapillaris. Based on the fundus photography, fundus autofluorescence, OCT angiography and en-face OCT imaging, the patient was diagnosed with juxtapapillary CNVM.

answers.answerText: D. Normal optical coherence tomography angiography

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: What is the treatment for this specific asymptomatic patient?

answers.explanation:
Though photodynamic therapy and intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment can be used if symptomatic, this patient has normal vision with no subjective complaints. If not impacting a high visual center like the fovea, this patient can be managed conservatively by follow-up with her referring retinal specialist. ​

**References:**

1. Jutley G, Jutley G, Tah V, Lindfield D, Menon G. Treating peripapillary choroidal neovascular membranes: a review of the evidence. Eye (Lond). 2011;25(6):675-681.

title: Case 1
description: 53F referred to ophthalmology to rule out melanocytoma OS
patientPresentation:
A 53-year-old asymptomatic female was referred to the ocular oncology service to rule out melanocytoma in the left eye. No past medical or ocular history was noted. Review of systems was unremarkable. Vision was 20/20 OU with normal IOP and anterior segment examination. Fundus examination of the right eye was normal. Fundus examination of the left eye revealed the following:

![](/content/media/oncology1-1_jpg_tif.webp)

\
Colour fundus: The optic nerve demonstrates a normal cup-to-disc ratio and colour. however, a raised dark-grey choroidal lesion over the temporal margin of the nerve is present, with a surrounding sub-retinal red lesion suggestive of hemorrhage.

![](/content/media/oncology1-2.webp)

FAF: Hypo-autofluorescent lesion temporal to optic disc corresponding to the lesion on the fundus photo (note: Subretinal hemorrhage attenuates lipofuscin signal from RPE) with a small area of hyper-autofluorescence in the superior aspect of the lesion, possibly attributed to denatured blood. 

You pull up a fundus photo and FAF of known melanocytoma that you saw earlier in your training for reference, which is shown below. Note the more prominent encroachment of the feathery lesion into the optic nerve head, with no red hue around the melanocytoma.

![](/content/media/oncology1-3_jpg_tif.webp)

![](/content/media/oncology1-4_jpg_tif.webp)

To help further characterize the lesion and associated hemorrhage, an OCT of the optic nerve OS was conducted and shown below: 

![](/content/media/oncology1-5.webp)

![](/content/media/oncology1-6.webp)

### Learning Objectives:​

1. To understand the OCT and OCT angiography features juxtapapillary CNVM.
2. To differentiate juxtapapillary CNVM from optic nerve melanocytoma.
